bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to P.M. Ashburn, April 15, 1922

div1.p: [Carter] thanks Ashburn for sending him his manuscript. He discusses issues concerning mosquitos, specifically the Anopheles.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to P.M. Ashburn, April 15, 1922
div1.opener:
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.
, D. C.
April 15, 1922.
Colonel P. M. Ashburn, M. C. U. S. A.,
Medical Field Service School,
Carlisle Barracks, Pa.
My Dear Doctor Ashburn:
div1.p:
I am very much obliged to you for your MSS, which I read with a great
deal of interest. In two of the main points I have long been interested:
1/ The breeding of Anopheles in the U. S. at a distance from the blood
supply furnished by man and the domestic animals dependent on man:
2/ Whether there is a difference in distance between the flight for
first blood for oviposition and the flights thereafter, which only could
be infecting flights.

To take the last matter first, I am inclined to think that there is--
that Anopheles will go farther in the first flight than subsequent ones.
The experiments that we have made with stained insects--not enough, of
course, to be determinative--have been greater in distance when made
with insects newly hatched than with those caught in houses the great
majority of which had fed.

I am going to ask that an old publication from my Service be sent you
touching upon this subject. If you get it, not Pages 33 and 34. Recent
observations by von Bremen in Batavia give a distance of flight of 2 1/2
kilometres whereas he states malaria is conveyed in that section to a-
bout 1 6/10 kilometres from the breeding places of the vectors. His ex-
perimental insects were newly developed--had never fed--but he does not
attention to this factor.

With regard to the first point, I had planned a survey of the prac-
tically uninhabited cypress swamps of eastern South Carolina and Georgia,
but have not been able to carry this out to any extent. Such little as
was done (on the Salkahatchie in S. C.) showed no Anopheles--that is, I
could find none, except within a reasonable distance of either men or
stock.

We have noted this symbiosis of the three Anopheles common east of the
Mississippi both with domestic animals and men. With the former it seems
closest, which is natural, as animals are always both more numerous and
more accessible to mosquitoes than the men at farm houses.

I have not found any special predeliction either for men or for ani-
mals with our Anopheles: It is rather a question, I think, of ready
access. Practically we do not find punctipennis in residences, except
in the cool weather of early spring and late fall: quadrimaculatus are es-
sentially a house mosquito so far as feeding is concerned: crucians ap-
parently somewhat between the two, if anything nearer punctipennis in
this habit.

I am inclosing an abstract of some work of Roubaud--not very recent--
but if you have not seen it, of interest to you. You will note that he--
and the same is true of both Sella and Grassi--considers that the blood
supply is an insignifigant factor in the production of Anopheles. This
may be true in Europe where there is doubtless always sufficient blood
supply within the distance of flight from any breeding place, but I am
quite sure is not so here.

I got your Military Hygiene from the Surgeon General's Library and read
the part referred to with much interest.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Enclosure.
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St.
